description: From Latin repercusus, past participle of repercutere (“to drive back”), from re- (“re-”) + percutere. See percussion.

verbs.description: repercuss (third-person singular simple present repercusses, present participle repercussing, simple past and past participle repercussed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, by extension) To reflect; to reverberate.
examples: Perceiving all the subjacent country,  […]  to repercuss such a light as I could hardly look against.
